ygData.subject: Interesting notes on evolving CTRNN substrates with HyperNEAT
ygData.msgSnippet: Hello there, I am using the following CPPN model for the substrate: Inputs: X1, Y1, X2, Y2, BIAS Outputs: Weight, Node-Bias, Node-Time_Constant The time

Subject: Interesting notes on evolving CTRNN substrates with HyperNEAT
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=283334584; y=M1Rp3AQ8i-m5roskfwJ7RRGiR5xovu8TQPg1AfwpZlyfTbo9Ho16iikphQ

Hello there, 

I am using the following CPPN model for the substrate: 

Inp=
uts: X1, Y1, X2, Y2, BIAS
Outputs: Weight, Node-Bias, Node-Time_Constant

T=
he time constant range is [0.5 .. 5.0] and the weight/node-bias range 
with=
in the substrate in [-8.0 .. 8.0]. 
The weight range in the CPPN is unbound=
ed. 

The node-specific outputs are computed using (X1, Y1, BIAS) and the 
=
others set to 0.

The activation functions used are plain sigmoid, gaussian=
, and sine. 
The CTRNN substrate activates with 0.02 timestep and it is use=
d to 
control a 3D humanoid model, simulated in a physical environment (usi=
ng 
Open Dynamics Engine http://www.ode.org ). 

The thing I notice, is the=
 following: 

The first networks are simple, and so the connective patterns=
 are. But 
the node biases and time constants are also simple. When I watch=
 an 
animaion of the activation changing in the substrate, it looks like it=
 
exibits a pattern. The simplest I've seen can be described as a mexican 
=
wave travelling across the hidden nodes. 
As the CPPNs complexify, so do th=
e activity patterns exibited. When 
using regular NEAT for the problem of k=
eeping the humanoid model 
balanced, it has moslty erratic behaviour, and t=
he lucky ones (with 
high fitness) usually find a way to trick the system a=
nd stay in a 
balanced position forever, without moving at all. 
But when H=
yperNEAT is used for this, it looks really interesting and.. 
natural! The =
model is trying to balance using its arms, and it is 
moving.. It looks lik=
e a drunk guy, but you note the difference. 
I've arranged the nodes in a g=
eometric way.. Let me explain - the left 
and right arm's outputs are separ=
ated in the left and right in the 
substrate space, and close to each other=
. So do the legs. The hidden 
nodes are in the center in a star/cirlular sh=
ape. I also included 3 
inputs (head velocity) in the center around 0.0, bu=
t with smaller 
radius than the ring of hidden nodes. 

Peter
